purpose_overview.goal: Achieve sustainable fat loss while maintaining muscle mass and supporting overall health through a 100% plant-based dietary approach.
purpose_overview.approach: Focus on whole, minimally processed plant foods — legumes, grains, vegetables, fruits, nuts, and seeds — combined with caloric restriction (≈15–25% below TDEE). Prioritize high protein, fiber-rich foods to optimize satiety and muscle preservation.
best_for: Individuals seeking fat loss with ethical, environmental, or health motivations
People with lactose intolerance or dairy avoidance
Those aiming for nutrient-dense, high-fiber diets
purpose_overview.why_it_works: Vegan diets are naturally lower in calorie density and higher in fiber, improving satiety and reducing overeating. Controlled trials show plant-based diets can support fat loss, cardiometabolic improvements, and long-term adherence when properly balanced.

caloric_strategy.maintenance: Estimate TDEE using Mifflin-St Jeor or activity multipliers.
caloric_strategy.fat_loss: 15–25% below TDEE for ~0.5–1% body weight loss per week.
caloric_strategy.muscle_gain: Possible but requires calorie surplus and careful protein planning.
caloric_strategy.body_recomposition: At maintenance calories, combining resistance training + high protein supports lean mass retention.

macronutrient_breakdown.protein: 1.8–2.4 g/kg/day; emphasize legumes, soy, seitan, quinoa, soy/pea/rice protein powders.
macronutrient_breakdown.carbohydrates: 45–55% of kcal from whole grains, legumes, fruits, vegetables.
macronutrient_breakdown.fats: 20–30% of kcal from nuts, seeds, avocados, plant oils; ensure omega-3 ALA sources.
macronutrient_breakdown.fiber: 35–55 g/day, naturally high in plant-based diets.

meal_timing_distribution.protein_distribution: 0.4–0.5 g/kg per meal; combine complementary proteins (e.g., rice + beans).
meal_timing_distribution.post_workout: Soy or pea/rice protein shake + carbs (fruit, grains).
meal_timing_distribution.evening_meal: Moderate protein + fibrous vegetables to support satiety.

supplements_recommended: Vitamin D3 (Vegan source) – For bone and immune health.
Omega-3 (Algae Oil) – EPA/DHA support since ALA conversion is limited.
Protein Powder (Soy, Pea/Rice blend) – Helps reach protein targets.
Creatine Monohydrate – Supports strength and lean mass.
Iron/Zinc – If deficient, with medical guidance.

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Weekly average – Adjust calories if progress stalls for >2 weeks.
monitoring_adjustments.strength_performance: Weekly – Ensure adequate protein and energy for recovery.
monitoring_adjustments.nutrient_status: Every 6–12 months – Monitor B12, Vitamin D, iron, zinc.
monitoring_adjustments.satiety_energy: Daily – Adjust protein/fiber/carbohydrate balance to sustain energy.

advantages: Naturally high in fiber → strong satiety and appetite control.
Lower calorie density aids fat loss without excessive restriction.
Ethical and environmental benefits may improve adherence.
Supports athletic performance with proper planning.
limitations: Risk of nutrient deficiencies (B12, D, iron, zinc, calcium, iodine, omega-3).
Requires careful protein planning and supplementation.
Higher food volume may cause GI discomfort for some.
Processed vegan foods (mock meats, snacks) may hinder fat loss.
scientific_references: Barnard ND et al. (2015). Effectiveness of a low-fat vegan diet in improving body weight and glycemic control. Am J Clin Nutr, 100(2):469–477.

Melina V et al. (2016). Position of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics: Vegetarian diets. J Acad Nutr Diet, 116(12):1970–1980.
